awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Automated Pavement Evaluation Using Advanced Machine Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a software suite that allows highway owner-agencies such as cities and state Departments of Transportation (DOTs) to manage their pavement networks in a more rigorous and cost-effective manner, enabling more strategic use of maintenance and rehabilitation funds. The software suite can be readily expanded to include other civil infrastructure, such as airfield pavements, bridges, and rail and transit track systems. In addition, other assets associated with or in the vicinity of transportation facilities can be located, identified, and assessed. This mapping includes road signs, guard rails, paint markings, utilities, garbage bins, etc., which can be viewed as additional layers on the data visualization platform of the software suite. Finally, measures of transportation sustainability, resilience, and environmental impact may be assessed and visualized as yet another layer on the visualization software. This visualization provides owner-agencies an unbiased, straightforward platform to assist them in systematically moving towards more sustainable and resilient infrastructure.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an automated pavement evaluation software suite.  The suite will incorporate several coded and integrated machine learning and deep learning techniques used for the detection and classification of the extent and severity of critical pavement obstacles.  The algorithms seek to provide highly accurate, unbiased pavement condition assessments. The machine learning-based models use a comprehensive pavement image dataset, which considers twenty different pavement distresses for both flexible and rigid pavements as verified by pavement experts. Another capability of the software is its ability to pre-screen projects using internet street view images.  This capability may  allow agencies to crowd-source data for their own road networks using municipal vehicle fleets equipped with the supplied video capture and road roughness sensor system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Pavement condition assessment provides critically needed information allowing owner-agencies to make more cost-effective and consistent decisions as they manage their network of urban and/or rural pavements. Generally, pavement distress inspections are performed using sophisticated data collection vehicles and/or foot-on-ground surveys. A new software suite developed and copyrighted at the University of Missouri (MU) now opens the door for fully-automated, bias-free pavement infrastructure assessment. This has contributed to improved accuracy, cost effectiveness, and safety of monitoring and maintaining road and airfield pavements. Based upon this technology, Tiger Eye Engineering (TEE) was launched as a startup company - spun out of MU in the Fall of 2021.

In this project, the MU research team participated in the 2022 NSF Bay Area National I-Corps(TM) program. The program involved intensive entrepreneurial training sessions, product and value proposition development and feedback sessions, and entailed over 130 interviews with potential customers, collaborators and competitors. A key finding of the project was a pivot away from state highway agencies as primary customers. Instead, our interviews identified small- and medium-sized cities and metropolitan planning organizations as key strategic customers for TEE during its start-up phase. It was also determined that TEE should focus on being a software company, partnering with, rather than competing with existing transportation engineering firms. Based on TEE's active participation in this project, TEE was awarded the 'Spirit of I-CORPS Award,' which is given to the top team among approximately 20 participating teams exemplifying the spirit of the I-CORPS program. 

After completion of the intensive 7-week I-CORPS program, two of the TEE company partners embarked on a 10-month campaign of conducting additional interviews, exhibiting at major national conferences and expositions, and secured its first several paid projects. At the end of the 12-month project, TEE is a thriving start-up company. Two of TEEs founding partners, who participated in this I-CORPS program, credit the I-CORPS program in getting TEE on the right track in terms of identifying its priority product and service offerings, and moreover, in identifying its most promising customer bases.

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2024
Modified by: William G Buttlar
